private_information: Initial stack top-to-bottom: A, B, C, D where A is smallest and D is largest
left_agent.goal: Move the full stack of disks from the left peg to the right peg preserving size order (A on top, D on bottom).

middle_agent.goal: Support moves so the full stack ends up on the right peg preserving size order (A on top, D on bottom).

right_agent.goal: Receive the full stack of disks from the left peg and hold them in correct order (A on top, D on bottom).

orchestrator.goal: Produce a complete PDDL domain and problem pair that solves the Tower of Hanoi instance for a FastDownwards-compatible solver, moving the four-disk stack from left to right.

public_information: There are three pegs named left, middle, and right.
There are 4 disks labeled A smallest, then B, C, D largest.
Only one disk may be moved at a time.
A larger disk may never be placed on top of a smaller disk.
Initial state: left peg holds A (top), B, C, D (bottom). Middle and right are empty.
Goal: right peg holds A (top), B, C, D (bottom); left and middle are empty.

describe.system_prompt: You are the agent responsible for the left peg. Provide a clear, structured description of the local peg state and any local constraints or observations that are relevant to planning. Do not produce PDDL. Provide the output as plain text or a simple structured listing.
describe.prompt: Your name is left_agent. Use the environment public information and your private information to describe your local state and any constraints you see. Include the current stack top-to-bottom, which disks you can move initially, and any limitations. Also restate the shared global goal for context.

describe.system_prompt: You are the agent responsible for the middle peg. Provide a clear, structured description of the local peg state and any local constraints or observations that are relevant to planning. Do not produce PDDL. Provide the output as plain text or a simple structured listing.
describe.prompt: Your name is middle_agent. Use the environment public information and your private information to describe your local state and any constraints you see. Include the current stack top-to-bottom and which disks you could accept or move under the puzzle rules. Also restate the shared global goal for context.

describe.system_prompt: You are the agent responsible for the right peg. Provide a clear, structured description of the local peg state and any local constraints or observations that are relevant to planning. Do not produce PDDL. Provide the output as plain text or a simple structured listing.
describe.prompt: Your name is right_agent. Use the environment public information and your private information to describe your local state and any constraints you see. Include the current stack top-to-bottom and what final configuration you should hold. Also restate the shared global goal for context.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert in PDDL modeling and multi-agent orchestration for classical planning. Produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem file that are compatible with the FastDownwards planner. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Keep actions and predicates clear and unambiguous. Ensure the domain supports moving a single disk between pegs, enforces the one-disk-at-a-time rule, and enforces the no-larger-on-smaller constraint. Use predicates suitable for FastDownwards requirements and avoid extensions not supported by basic STRIPS where possible.
pddl.prompt: You are the orchestrator. You will receive structured descriptions from the three peg agents. Integrate their descriptions and the public information about the Tower of Hanoi instance to produce a complete PDDL domain and problem for the four-disk instance. The domain should model disks, pegs, disk sizes or ordering, and a move action that moves the top disk from one peg to another only if it is smaller than the destination peg's top disk or the destination is empty. The problem should encode the initial configuration with left peg holding A B C D (A top) and the goal with right peg holding A B C D (A top). Target the FastDownwards solver. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags.
